speech.para: But Rob is just like most of us. We gild the lily from time to time to gain some political advantage. Peter Reith went knocking on his door and said, `Mate, I've got this idea. I need you to beat it up a bit. I need you to give me some sort of estimation in terms of the sorts of jobs it will create.' So they had one beer and it was 30,000. They had another beer and it was 40,000. By the fifth beer it was 100,000. But commonsense prevailed and they thought that that was probably going to be pretty tough to convince anyone of, so it went back down to 50,000. So now it is 50,000 jobs. It is a bit like an auction, isn't it? I can just see them. They say, `It is going to be 50,000. Will we get away with that?' `Yes,' and it is once, twice, three times gone. This is the basis on which the government underpins this legislationâthe basis of a figure plucked straight out of the air.

This bill is about two things. It is not about economic growth and job opportunities. It is about ideology and it is about desperationâabsolute desperation. The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Businessâlike many others on the government frontbench, including the primary industries minister, the Treasurer and even the Prime Ministerâbrought to the job very high expectations. After 13 years on the opposition benches, they were prepared to say anything. They were going to offer the Australian community the world.

What has the minister for small business done for the small business community? Not a thing. This bill is about diverting attention. It is about diverting attention away from his failure to tackle the market dominance issue in the retail sector. The member for Blair talked about the Small Business show. The fact is that he is running around the country trying to instil in the small business community a perception that the world will be their oyster, if only he can get his unfair dismissal laws through the parliament.

We all know that 93 per cent of those who work in the small business community work under state awards. The minister knows that very well. Like the figure of 50,000 plucked out of the air, he knows that this is a furphy and a desperate attempt to cover up his failings.

subdebateinfo.title: Faces of the Gold Coast Mural

talk.start.para: âTonight I would like to bring to the House's attention a Work for the Dole scheme immortalising the faces of a hundred children that was launched in my electorate today. As I was unable to attend the launch, I wanted to bring the House's attention to the benefits of such a project in the McPherson electorate. `Faces of the Gold Coast' is the first project of its kind in Australia and will be of national significance. Not only will it beautify a stretch of the Pacific Highway but it will create work opportunities for youth in the McPherson electorate.

speech.para: `Faces of the Gold Coast' will engage 75 young unemployed people who will effectively paint the faces of a hundred children along the highway in a brightly-coloured collage interspersed with Gold Coast flora. Not only will it develop a new image for a stretch of the highway and, in particular, the ugly noise barriers but it will provide our young unemployed persons with the opportunity of working on the artistic beautification of their community. It also means they will participate in invaluable work experience that gives each of them a chance to learn essential workplace skills and work ethics that will lead to paid long-term employment. It is planned that the mural will be completed fully by Australia Day 1999.

This project explores the ethnic make-up of our community and will provide a visual celebration showing the McPherson electorate as one made up of people from many cultures living together harmoniously. The project has drawn together many sections of our community, from preschoolers to high school students, teachers, parents, grandparents and unemployed youth. The faces of the children were selected through a process whereby the children themselves, their families or teachers nominated portraits of children between the ages of one and 18. Today at the launch a hundred faces were drawn at random from a barrel, and those faces of local children will be painted on the walls in a trail of public art which will last up to 20 years.

`Faces of the Gold Coast' follows two similar highly successful projects run by not-for-profit organisation Phantast. All three projects were made possible through a Work for the Dole initiative known as the Suburban Centre Improvement Project. For me one of the most heartening aspects is that, in the first project initiated by Phantast involving 120 unemployed youth, 82 per cent of participants at the conclusion of the project entered paid employment. A tremendous effort, Mr Speaker. Without a commitment by the federal government, support from Dulux, which supplied all the paint, and the dedication of the two project coordinatorsâJune Hintz and Calvin Pybusâour youth would not have such opportunities.

It is my intention to further develop Work for the Dole schemes within my electorate leading to more long-term, full-time jobs for our youth. I would recommend such a scheme to anybody who is unemployed. As well as developing essential skills, participants develop the confidence and motivation to secure paid employment. In this particular project, a major benefit is that youth develop visual resumes which will be seen by residents and visitors to the Gold Coast in the 80,000 cars which travel the highway daily. This high visible exposure of the art gives off a sophisticated and positive image and a welcome message to our interstate and international travellers. It creates a lasting impressionâan impression that will remain in the community for the next 20 years.

For our local residents, it develops a unifying link and creates a psychologically pleasing environment and an opportunity to unite as one. The public artwork will become a tourism landmark, and it is envisaged that within five years all the facesâthe real life childrenâwill meet at the site for a reunion and reflect on the unity which occurred on the highway today. I look forward to reporting to the House on the success of this project and further Work for the Dole projects in the McPherson electorate.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to speak about industrial relationsâan extremely important issue for the whole community. We are facing one of the grossest attacks on workers' rights that we have faced for a long time. Persistently under this government we have suffered abuses. We have suffered abuses at the waterfront. We suffered abuses when the Workplace Relations Act was first introduced in 1996. We now have a new attack on workers and their job security by this government, which is not even prepared to allow our second speaker the opportunity of debating.

speech.para: We have a number of very important issues to raise in respect of industrial relations, and the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business parades around here as if this bill that was before the parliament earlier today is going to be another feather in his cap. He parades around here, in dinner suit and all, saying that this is a feather in the cap for productivity in the nation, for creating jobs, for freeing up the market, for opportunities for business. He parades around saying, `Look at me. I am going to be the saviour of the nation.' What I say to the minister is that the feather looks to me more like a feather in a peacock's tail. It is all about pride and strutting around and showing off. There is actually no substance; it is just there for decoration.

Workers in this country deserve security. The myth that this bill is about small business cannot be sustained. This bill is about every single new employee in every workplace that is covered by federal legislationâbecause the first six months of employment for any employee, whether they are employed by a business with 15 people or less, will be caught by this act. There are some extremely difficult technical provisions in the workplace relations amendments that are being suggested which have not been debated in this House, and they are vitally important for our community.

I do not even think this parliament yet understands that part of this proposal is the difference between unfair dismissals and unlawful dismissals. Most of the people in this House would think that if you have under 15 employees this bill means you can sack people with gay abandon. You will be able to sack people unfairly if you have an employer who is even handed in his abuse of his employees. He is allowed to dismiss people. If he is discriminatory in the way he abuses his employees, then we will have a claim, and that employee will be able to go off to the courtâbut no longer the commissionâto raise their claim.

What sort of a nonsense is this process? What sort of a nonsense is it, except the minister wants to parade around in front of the small business community saying, `We are offering some fantastic job creation program'? Frankly, it is very hard for our community to believe that this minister is interested in creating jobs. He is certainly not interested in providing any security for the workers in our community.

talk.start.para: âWhere is he now? He's gone back to dinner.

âHe has gone back to dinner; that is right. He is not very worried about this debate. He tells us that we cannot speak on it. I say to this parliament and to the community that, if this government are not concerned about security of employment for their employees, they do not deserve to govern. Job security should be one of the key issues of concern for this government, but it is not.

speech.para: If you are in the first six months of your employment, you miss out. If you work for an employer who has fewer than 15 employees, you miss out. What happens if you work with 30 employees but 15 are employed by one company and 15 are employed by another? This is just not Patrick's; we do not need a grand strategy like Patrick's to be able to get into this situation. Textile, clothing and footwear companies all across the country already try to abuse provisions to get out of paying termination and severance payments in situations of redundancies. What is to say that they will not use these provisions to be able to avoid their obligations to treat their employees fairly? What is to say that other industries will not do the same thing?

Casual employees are not counted. What will happen? I can work with 40 employees. I need to know whether 18 of them are casual. If 18 of them are casual, I need to know the hours they work. I need to work out whether that is regular and systematic employment and then I will be able to work out whether or not I actually have job security and am entitled to be treated with some fairness and dignity. But this government does not care about fairness and dignity, and it does not care about security of employment. I think it is a great shame that we have seen this absolute charade in this parliament today. The minister pretends he is interested in creating jobs and he pretends he is interested in security for employees.

talk.start.para: âTalking about job security, the last speaker, the member for Gellibrand, should recall that before the advent of Gough Whitlam we had 1Â½ per cent unemployment in this country. I was working as a labourer at the time for two or three years and I must say I really appreciated that, because we took great delight in making life fairly unpleasant for our employers on a regular basis but they had to take it. They could not sack us because there was no-one else to put in our place. When Mr Whitlam came in and introduced a 25 per cent across-the-board cut of all tariffs in Australia, he most certainly removed that part of Australian life for good. The honourable member for Reid laughs. Mr Whitlam took a 25 per cent across-the-board cutâ

âI will continue. I spoke about prime interest rates being a way to help our Australian industries combat trade from overseas and imports coming into this country. speech.para: The government is in an enormously powerful position to help Australian industry. I have mentioned government contracts. One in four motor vehicles in this country is purchased by the government. Government purchasing power enabled the Holden motor car in this country to get away to a very wonderful start. In Queensland, where I was part of the government for many years, we used government contracts very, very extensively to help our own local industry. One newspaper report stated that a 10th of the computers purchased in Australia are purchased by Australian government.

One of the great unsung heroes in the steel industryâand it pains me to admit it, as he was from the other side of the Houseâwas John Button. Very few people really appreciate the significance of the Button plan in Australia. One worker in the steel industry in Australia was producing 80 tonnes of steel a year, whereas one worker in the Kaohsiung plant in Taiwan was producing 600 tonnes. That was how hopelessly inefficient the steel industry in Australia was. Obviously, it would have to be destroyed if Australia were to be internationally competitive in all other industries.

John Button promised them $350 millionâI thought that was rather clever because they never got the $350 million; all they ever got was $170 millionâon the condition that they put $1,000 million in and the unions came to the party. The net result of that was the industry rose to a point where one worker in the steel industry in Australia was producing 620 tonnes of steel and the industry was probably as efficient as any other industry in Australia.

For those who say that the steel industry is having bad problems again, I just say that we got 10 magnificent years out of that industry. Unfortunately, some very dreadful mistakes were made in Western Australia which have cost the industry dearly and have set it back again. I saw John Button in the main street in Melbourne and I said to him, `You rescued the Australian car industry, made the Australian steel industry competitive and got sacked for your achievements.' He said, `You're right on all three counts,' and smiled and walked off. He was proving the economic rationalist policies of the Keating years to be wrong.

Government infrastructureâthe building of dams, the building of that magnificent port of Gladstone in Queensland and the building of roadsâenables us to work on economies of scale that enable us to be the most efficient producers in the world. I bless, as every Queenslander blesses, those wonderful years of great government in Queenslandâthe Bjelke-Petersen yearsâthat are much maligned by our opponents on the other side of the House. They built this port and said, `It will be world's best practice. It will be built on the best economies of scale that exist in the world. We will use coal loaders that the rest of the world can only dream of because of their size, and this port will take ships of 200,000 tonnes.' There are only six ports in the entire world that take ships of that size.

We built a huge power station which produced the cheapest electricity in the world because of its enormous size. We were able to produce coal cheaper than anyone else in the world and we are still producing coal cheaper than anyone else in the world today, because the government was prepared to invest money to help industry. talk.start.para: âI rise on this occasion to add my voice to the voices of complaint from the opposition about the disgraceful conduct of the government tonight in gagging the important debate on the Workplace Relations Amendment (Unfair Dismissals) Bill. We could have no more grand example of arrogance and high-handedness than to watch the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business scuttle back into this chamber, dressed in a dinner suitâobviously with somewhere more important to goâonly to participate in a division which gagged this important debate on a piece of legislation which he knows, and every member of this House should know, is fundamentally bad public policy. One has to assume that the coalition members opposite sought the opportunity to gag this debate because they know that, if the debate was allowed to go to its full potential, ultimately they could not defend this piece of legislation.

speech.para: The legislation is bad public policy on three clear counts. First, it is bad public policy because it takes us further and further away from the International Labour Organisation convention dealing with termination of employment. In a world in which we are dealing with globalisation and increased insecurity, when every mind and mood study and every attitudinal study of the Australian population will tell you that working people are crying out for security, crying out to know that they will be in jobs tomorrow, that they will be able to meet their mortgage payments tomorrow and that they will be able to feed their kids tomorrow, it is somehow the answer of government members not to deal with the full debate, not to deal with globalisation and not to deal with one of the buttresses against globalisation which is of course spreading international labour regulation throughout the world. Instead of dealing with that public policy debate, their answer to those feelings of insecurity is to introduce and ram through this House a piece of legislation which will make it easier for employers to sack workers. It is fundamentally bad public policy, short-sighted and ridiculous for anybody who is trying to deal with these major public policy questions.

Secondly, it is bad public policy because it means for workers in small businesses with fewer than 15 employees that you can be treated with almost any act of unfairness. The magic number is 15 employees; apparently something major happens if you get to 16 employees. This is the minister's `through the looking glass' approach.

Prior to coming into this House, I worked as an industrial solicitor for eight years at Slater and Gordon and I was proud to do so and proud to represent working people and trade unions. I was also proud to work with a woman called Kate Hawkins, who is now a partner of that firm and who ran a case that I would like to tell you about briefly. It was a case involving a worker in a rural bus depot, a small business with fewer than 15 employees. The boss of the depot allowed his german shepherd to range at will, unrestrained. This worker was constantly being harassed by the dog until one morning it bit him. With blood coming out of his legâit was a severe biteâhe went to the boss and said, `I am having a bit of a problem with the dog. Would you mind chaining the dog up?' to which the boss said, `If that is your attitude, you can go.' And that worker was dismissed.

Under your piece of legislation, that worker would have no rights at all to complain about the dismissalâwhich only goes to prove that, under this minister and under this government's regime, if it ever comes to a confrontation between a worker and a dog, you know who this government is going to back. They are going to back the dog. They showed it down at Patrick's and on the wharves during the confrontation down there. They preferred the dogs to the workers and they continue to show it now.

Thirdly, this piece of legislation is bad public policy because, as the member for Gellibrand pointed out, it can be manipulated by any sharp employer who divides his or her work force between more than one company in order to come under the number of 15 employees. It is bad on three counts, three strikes. It ought to have been out, but you did not have the courage, you did not have the guts and you did not have the tenacity to come in here tonight and meet us speaker for speaker, point by point, because you knew that you could not handle the debate. That is the hallmark of this minister and the hallmark of this government on industrial relations.

I will make a prediction now that you will try to do the same on every piece of industrial relations legislation that you bring into this House in the coming weeks of sitting, and next year, because you know that, on the merits, you cannot defend it. You are playing to a constituency that you are seeking to wrap up in GST tape and you are trying desperately to claw some votes back there before your new tax compliance burden hits them. You are not going to win that debate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIt is timely that I bring to the House's attention tonight an innovative and creative look at the future for passenger transport over waterâstraight from my electorate of Gilmore which, as many here will know, is the environmental icon of Australia.

speech.para: Over the next few weeks, the Renewable Energy Showcase grants will be decided between the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources and the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. The showcase represents the government's support for this country's most important and potentially lucrative projects developed by local inventors, manufacturers and dreamers.

Solar Sailor, which was once the dream of a Gilmore resident, Dr Robert Dane, is now a reality which this country can use as an example of what can be achieved if we act upon our dreams and if we have the courage and experience to support such an innovative idea. Solar Sailor is a wholly Australian-owned company which has developed a new application for existing technologyâsolar power. This application makes passenger transport by solar power and other forms of renewable energy a reality this century.

Solar Sailor's first vessel, a solar ferry on Sydney Harbour, is destined to be a world first, and I am delighted to say that this world first will become a reality because of the belief of Dr Robert Dane, his colleagues and the residents of Ulladulla who have wholeheartedly supported this venture. The solar powered ferry would be a highly visible way of showcasing Australia's advanced marine and renewable energy technology to the world, particularly in time for the Sydney 2000 Olympics. As a nation which will be priding itself on the green games, what better way can Australia show this than providing renewable energy transport for the many visitors who will be attending the games from throughout the worldânot to mention the obvious benefits for the environment and the multimillion dollar investment this will mean for Ulladulla, for local business and particularly for employment.

Ulladulla is a stunning coastal town in the south of my electorateâthe perfect setting for the construction and sea trials of this vessel. The Solar Sailor team includes naval architect Graham Parker, solar computer and marine engineers in Ulladulla and Sydney and business support from Panasonic, BP Solar, Venture Corp Australia, as well as engineers Robert Pongrass and John Patterson.

They have received support not just from the local community but also from some of the most influential business people in the country and companies at the cutting edge of renewable energy technology. The first seven-metre prototype, the Marjorie K, travelled at 15 knots on a sunny day in eight- to 10-knot winds. The larger the vessel the more improved the performance, with the potential for environmentally sensitive solar powered cruise ships or cargo vessels a reality. The Marjorie K was judged the most innovative vessel at last year's international Solar Advanced Technology Boat Race here in Canberra on Lake Burley Griffin.
Solar wings on the ferry provide the opportunity for sailing into headwinds, recharging the vessel at sea and harnessing the power of the sun and wind.
